answers.explanation: This patient has inferior arcuate defects in both eyes. The defect is more significant in the right eye and is only located in the inferior meridian.

OCT RNFL and Ganglion Cell Inner Plexiform Layer (GCIPL) Analysis were performed and shown above.  What is the most significant finding?

answers.explanation: On the OCT RNFL thickness map, there is a striking difference in the thickness of the superior optic nerve compared to the inferior optic nerve. The superior RNFL is significantly thinned OU. As this patient is less than 18, normative data is not present.

Fundus photography was performed and is shown above. What is the patient's most likely diagnosis?

answers.answerText: C. Superior segmental optic nerve hypoplasia
answers.explanation:
This patient has superior segmental optic nerve hypoplasia. Closer inspection of the posterior pole reveals relative superior entrance of the central retinal artery (red arrow), pallor of the superior disc (purple asterisks), and thinning of the superior peri-papillary nerve fibre layer (yellow asterisks).

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: What maternal medical condition/finding is thought to be associated with optic nerve hypoplasia?

answers.explanation:
For reasons unknown, there is an association between optic nerve hypoplasia and maternal diabetes mellitus. In a study conducted by Kim et al, all 10 patients with superior segmental optic nerve hypoplasia were born to mothers with diabetes mellitus. Optic nerve hypoplasia may also be associated with fetal alcohol syndrome and premature birth.

References

Kim RY, Hoyt WF, Lessell S, Narahara MH. Superior Segmental Optic Hypoplasia: A Sign of Maternal Diabetes. Arch Ophthalmol. 1989;107(9):1312–1315.

questions.title: Question 5
questions.text: What issues are patients with optic nerve hypoplasia at risk of developing?

answers.explanation: While optic nerve hypoplasia cannot be reversed or treated, it is a non-progressive entity. These patients are at risk for development of hormonal insufficiencies (thyroid hormone, growth hormone, adrenal gland, anti-diuretic hormone deficiencies) as a result of hypothalamic dysfunction. These patients should be referred for endocrine work-up as hormonal deficiencies may not manifest until adulthood.
